data.text: Contents
Introduction

The MSE Radiology Departments receive multiple requests for various examinations on a daily basis. Many of these procedures involve administering Intravenous Contrast Media (IVCM) and doses of ionising radiation to the patient. It is important that the patient receives the correct examination to answer the clinical question being asked, and also that the Trust complies with current regulations on ionising radiation. Therefore an appropriately qualified healthcare professional is required to vet these requests prior to the patient having the examination.
Prompt vetting, appointing and reporting of radiology exams are key to ensuring fast patient diagnosis and treatment. This policy sets out the following:-
The roles and responsibilities of the individual completing the vetting
Expected timeframes for the vetting of referrals made to the radiology service

Certain Plain film X-ray, Computed Tomography (CT), Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) and fluoroscopy procedures can be vetted by radiographers. Certain Ultrasound referrals may be vetted by sonographers. Specific information regarding vetting guidelines can be found in the schemes of work documents for each modality where applicable. The remaining examinations are to be vetted by radiologists.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:
Specify which healthcare professionals are responsible for vetting the various radiology procedures.
Indicate the requirements for IVCM for those procedures as applicable – in line with the relevant PGD.
Ensure that all exposures of ionising radiation to patients attending the Radiology Department are authorised / vetted by the appropriate health care professional.
Ensure that all exposures of ionising radiation to patients during diagnostic examinations are justified under IR(ME)R 2017 requirements.
Set out the expected timeframes for the vetting of referrals made to the Radiology service.
Definitions

data.text: Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Committee responsibilities (i.e. Medicines Committees)
MSE Radiology Governance Board; Ratification of this policy.
MSE Radiation Protection Committee; to discuss, approve and amend this policy as appropriate.
Individual responsibilities (i.e. Chief Executive)

Chief Executive – As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring Mid and South Essex NHS Foundation Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Medical Physics Expert / Radiation Protection Advisor; to give advice on matters relating to ionising radiation as detailed in IR(ME)R17 / IRR17.
Radiology Staff; to vet procedures in accordance with this policy.
Superintendent Radiographers / modality leads; to ensure this policy is readily available to all Radiology staff.
Vetting aims
To vet and protocol all urgent inpatient and Emergency Department requests as soon as possible and at least on the same working day.
To vet and protocol all cancer pathway and urgent referrals within 1 day (24 hours) excluding weekends.
To vet and protocol all other requests within 3 days of referral (72 hours) excluding weekends.

If a radiologist or radiographer needs to discuss/liaise with referring clinicians, this action should be recorded on the Radiology Information System (RIS). The radiologist/radiographer is responsible for following up of this.
Vetting escalation triggers
Vetting Discrepancies (i.e. where the clinical information does not clearly justify the study and there is a need for additional information)

If there is a discrepancy with a referral, it is the responsibility of the Radiologist /Radiographer /Sonographer to contact the referring team for more information. This will be either by phone or email, depending on the level of urgency and most appropriate method at the time. It is the responsibility of the referrer to respond and supply additional information for the examination to proceed. All vetting discrepancies are expected to be resolved within 72 hours, after this time the escalation process should be followed to ensure prompt resolution.
At the Basildon site, if the vetting individual is unable to contact the referrer then the request will be cancelled with a note to the referrer.
Cancer pathway (Fast Track)
Referrals for patients on a cancer pathway are expedited both in terms of appointment and completion of report.
Requests for imaging should be vetted within 24 hours of referral excluding weekends.
Urgent Outpatients
Requests are to be vetted the same working day excluding weekends.
Routine Outpatients
Routine outpatient requests are to be vetted within 3 working days excluding weekends.
Escalation processes
Cases waiting for 2 working days or more beyond the expected timeframes (without a valid documented justification)
These shall be escalated to the appropriate sub-specialty Radiologists or the modality Lead (Radiographers / Sonographers)
Note: the 2 week wait cancer referrals are monitored daily at the Daily Radiology Cancer Call meeting.

Cases waiting more than 1 week beyond the expected timeframes (without a valid documented justification) shall be escalated to the Radiology Site Clinical Lead by the nominated manager and/or Modality lead as appropriate. This action should be recorded on the Radiology Information System (RIS). The Radiologist / Radiographer is responsible for following up of this.
Exceptional cases waiting for more than 3 weeks beyond the expected timeframes (e.g. MRI safety queries)

After the department has taken all appropriate action and if the referrer has still not replied, the Modality Leads / Deputies / admin team or nominated individual shall refer the request ‘back to source' stating the reason for cancellation. An e-mail or letter (copied to the referrer/referring team and secretary where applicable) will ask the requester to create a new referral once all necessary information has been provided. This will be recorded on RIS.
The individual completing the vetting and who cancels a request by e-mail or letter should include the relevant modality lead in that final correspondence. This will be recorded on RIS.

At the Basildon site, this is an electronic process whereby the cancellation reason and initials of the Radiologists cancelling the procedure is recorded in RIS and this message goes to the referrer as an automated email.
Vetting radiology referrals
Before justifying a procedure the following should be taken into account;
Appropriateness of referral.
Cross check clinical information justifies the examination.
Cross check patient demographics against clinical information provided.
Cross check previous examinations and investigations.
Check age, gender and other patient details (is there an alternative modality available that will reduce radiation and/or IVCM exposure to the patient).
Requests for follow up studies (e.g. pulmonary nodule follow up, post chemo/radiotherapy) must have a stated date or timeframe for when the repeat study is required.
Examinations can be vetted in two ways:
Procedures can be ‘vetted' by a practitioner electronically on the RIS system against that request.

A Practitioner can verbally vet a procedure by authorising it via a conversation held with the referrer or operator. A record of this conversation should be made on the RIS notepad/cloud/comment section associated with that procedure.
Vetting plain film X-Ray requests.

These requests are vetted by qualified Radiographers. Radiographers follow departmental guidelines based on those set out by the Royal College of Radiologists in iRefer guidelines ‘Making the best use of clinical radiology'. If necessary the Radiographer can escalate the vetting of complex cases to a Radiologist, Radiology Registrar or an Advanced Practitioner Reporting Radiographer. By vetting the procedure, the Radiographer/Radiologist is acting as Practitioner under IR(ME)R17 and therefore justifying the radiation exposure to the patient.

data.text: Certain complex plain film examinations must be vetted by a Consultant Radiologist
Vetting MRI requests.
Certain procedures may be vetted by the MRI Radiographers as per the agreed departmental scheme of work.

These requests are vetted by the Radiographers signed off as ‘authorised personnel' in MRI scanning. If necessary the Radiographers can escalate the vetting of complex cases to a Radiologist or Radiology Registrar.

There is no associated dose of ionising radiation therefore the IR(ME)R17 does not require consideration. There are, however, many safety aspects and contraindications to MRI (e.g. pacemaker), that require careful consideration prior to authorising an MRI request. For further information see the departmental MRI operational policy.

There are PGDs in place to enable Radiographers to administer contrast medium in the absence of a Radiologist. The referrals must be in line with both the departmental protocols and the PGD guidelines/criteria.
Unless otherwise stated on the RIS notepad the Radiographers will carry out the standard protocol as per the agreed departmental protocol.

All Inpatient and ED requests are vetted by the duty Radiologist. This can also be performed by any other Radiologist or authorised MRI Radiographer if the duty Radiologist is not available where applicable.
At the Basildon site, MRI - Inpatient and ED requests are vetted by the MRI
Urgent Radiologist.
Vetting ultrasound requests
These requests are vetted by Sonographers, Consultant Radiologists or Senior Mammographers, depending on the complexity of the case.
There is no associated dose of ionising radiation however, it is essential that each referral is reviewed and assessed for its appropriateness to ensure best patient care and appropriate imaging.
All Inpatient and ED requests are vetted by the duty Radiologist. This can also be performed by any other Radiologist or Sonographer if the duty Radiologist is not available where applicable.
Vetting CT requests
Certain procedures may be vetted by appropriately trained and approved CT Radiographers as per the agreed departmental scheme of work.
There are a number of pre-authorised procedures which may be undertaken given clinical criteria e.g. Stroke, Trauma Head scan – see specific document.
By vetting the procedure, the individual is acting as a Practitioner under IR(ME)R17 and therefore justifying the radiation exposure to the patient.
By vetting, the individual is justifying the use of IVCM.. The administration of the IVCM is under the PGD.
Unless otherwise stated on the RIS notepad the Radiographers will carry out the standard protocol as per the departmental protocol.

All Inpatient and ED requests are vetted by the duty Radiologist. This can also be performed by any other Radiologist or authorised CT Radiographer (for set examinations) if the duty Radiologist is not available.
Vetting Fluoroscopy requests
Certain fluoroscopic procedures may be vetted by the fluoroscopy trained Radiographers as per the agreed departmental scheme of work for Radiographers vetting fluoroscopic procedures.
By vetting the procedure, the individual is acting as Practitioner under IR(ME)R and therefore justifying the radiation exposure to the patient.
Unless otherwise stated on the RIS notepad the Radiographers will carry out the standard protocol as per the departmental protocol folder.
Vetting Nuclear Medicine exams
Nuclear medicine requests (with the exception of PET CT requests) are predominantly vetted by nuclear medicine radiographers / technicians with any complex cases being vetted by Radiologists
Vetting all other diagnostic imaging requests.
All other diagnostic imaging requests are vetted by a Radiologist or Radiology Registrar.

Unless otherwise stated by the Radiologist; Radiographers will carry out the standard protocol as per the departmental protocol. Reasons for any deviation from the standard protocol will be documented on RIS by the Operator/Radiographer.
Imaging requests for emergency Imaging examinations outside of normal working hours
Outside of normal working hours urgent CT referrals are vetted and discussed with either the on-call Radiologist or the out-of-hours outsourced reporting provider as applicable.

Outside of normal working hours with the exception of plain film and CT as described above, all requests for emergency examinations must be discussed with the on-call Radiologist; he/she is contactable via switchboard.

Following verbal approval of the request the referring clinician must notify the duty Radiographer that the examination has been approved by the on-call Radiologist. A record is made of this conversation via a vetting note on the RIS electronic notepad, documenting the name of the Radiologist authorising the procedure.
The duty Radiographer will then vet the examination on the RIS system and proceed with carrying out the examination.
Under IR(ME)R the Radiologist is still acting as Practitioner by verbally approving the procedure.
Unless otherwise stated by the Radiologist or via the referring clinician Radiographers/Assistant Practitioners will carry out the standard protocol as per the departmental protocol.
Changes and cancellations of imaging requests.

A small proportion of Diagnostic Imaging requests are declined at the vetting stage. In many cases, further clinical information is required in order to justify the procedure and ensure that the correct imaging test/modality is utilised to answer the clinical question.
It is the responsibility of the Diagnostic Imaging Department to ensure that the referrer is informed that the request for imaging has been declined.
Forms of communication can include;

If a decision is made to change the examination to another Imaging modality or to cancel part of the examination requested, this will be documented on as part of the patients imaging record (this can be on the RIS notepad or in the Imaging report.)

At the Basildon site, this is an electronic process whereby the cancellation reason and initials of the radiologists cancelling the procedure is recorded in RIS and this message goes to the referrer as an automated email.
Training requirements
No specific training requirements.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Diagnostic Imaging Governance group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Diagnostic Imaging Governance group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
